elements.content: V-shaped ligands are commonly used for helical coordination polymer synthesis. However, employment of multiple V-shaped ligands does not always lead to a helical network. The mutual interplay of two V-shaped ligands, which is neither easily predictable nor well documented, plays a major role directing the self-assembly of the resultant network. We report here the construction of a series of novel coordination polymers {[Ni(OBA)(H2MDP)(H2O)]·(DMF)3} n (1),{[Ni(FBA)(H2MDP)]·(H2O)3·(DMF)} n (2),{[Ni2(IPA)2(H2MDP)2(H2O)]·(H2O)(DMF)} n (3),{[Ni(ADA)(H2MDP)]·(MeOH)} n (4),[Ni(TNBA)(H2MDP)2] n (5), {[Ni(PPA)(H2MDP)2]·(H2O)2} n (6), {[Ni(HDPA)2(H2MDP)2]} n (7), and [Ni(SBA)(H2MDP)] n (8) {where H2OBA = 4,4′-oxybis(benzoic acid), H2FBA = 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid), H2IPA = isophthalic acid, H2ADA =1,3-adamantanediacetic acid, H2TNBA = 5,5′-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzoic acid), H2PPA 1,4-phenylenedipropionic acid, H2DPA = diphenic acid H2SBA= 4,4′-sulfonyldibenzoic acid} using a combination of mixed V-shaped ligands. The deployment of bent ligands yields a rich variety of network topologies with various helical motifs comprising both the linkers and the individual one. A detailed gas sorption study of porous networks, as evident from the presence of distinct nanoporous voids and channels inside the structures, is also investigated. Furthermore, chirality associated with helical networks and their role as potential functional materials are verified by solid state circular dichroism spectra.

elements.content: We report herein a series of Ni(II) based MOFs obtained by mutual interplay between two V-shaped pyrazole and carboxylate-based linker molecules. Various possible helical motifs generated from such interactions have successfully been classified, and furthermore adsorptive capacity and chiral nature of these MOFs are also investigated.

elements.content: Synthesis and rational design of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) as functional materials has attained considerable attention in recent times owing to their various intriguing applications in both biological and material science fields. Of particular significance are the versatile functionalized MOFs that are relatively easy to synthesize via rational structural tuning. Incorporation of functional groups inside a fine-tuned structural framework can be conceived as the most important cornerstone of any functional materials design. For instance, porous functionalized MOFs due to their high surface area, tunable framework, and adjustable pore sizes have emerged, inter alia, as a promising candidate as absorbent for gas storage and separation.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Synthesis and rational design of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as functional materials has attained considerable attention in recent times owing to their various intriguing applications in both biological and material science fields. Of particular significance are the versatile functionalized MOFs that are relatively easy to synthesize via rational structural tuning. Incorporation of functional groups inside a fine-tuned structural framework can be conceived as the most important cornerstone of any functional materials design. For instance, porous functionalized MOFs due to their high surface area, tunable framework, and adjustable pore sizes have emerged, inter alia, as a promising candidate as absorbent for gas storage and separation.

elements.content: One of the challenging areas of MOF synthesis is the construction of bioinspired helical networks, which are potent candidates for enantiomorph separation, biologic pharmacy, asymmetric catalysis, nonlinear optics, gas storage and separation, etc. In general, deployment of V-shaped flexible ligands, typically an anionic O-donor ligand or neutral N-donor ligand, with suitable metal centers has proven to be the most successful strategy for helical MOF synthesis. Formation of a helical network in MOFs with a single bent ligand is now well documented. However; helical polymeric networks with mixed V-shaped ligands have rarely been reported. This could be attributed to the difficulty in rational incorporation of multiple flexible linkers in the network, and subsequently the desired control of the self-assembly process has remained a great challenge for helical MOF synthesis. We have recently published our investigations concerning the structural aspects of some metal directed MOFs that were generated using mixed V-shaped ligand systems, each capable of forming helical networks. Inspired by the aforesaid facts, we now extend our work along these lines by employing a range of flexible V-shaped poly(carboxylic acid)s as an auxiliary ligand along with a bispyrazole based ligand, methylenebis(3,5-dimethylpyrazole) (H2MDP) (Scheme ). It is noteworthy here that the H2MDP molecule with a flexible V-shaped conformation possesses structural characteristics that are considered to be prerequisite for helical network construction, whereas all individual poly(carboxylic acid)s have already been effectively used for construction of helical networks. Our primary aim is to gain a deeper insight into the structural interplay between two ligands and the interaction hierarchy between molecular functionalities of the two ligands on the metal center. Accordingly we report herein synthesis, characterization, structural analyses of eight MOFs, {[Ni(OBA)(H2MDP)(H2O)]·(DMF)3} n (1), {[Ni(FBA)(H2MDP)]·(H2O)3·(DMF)} n (2), {[Ni2(IPA)2(H2MDP)2(H2O)]·(H2O)(DMF)} n (3), {[Ni(ADA)(H2MDP)]·(MeOH)} n (4), [Ni(TNBA)(H2MDP)2] n (5), {[Ni(PPA)(H2MDP)2]·(H2O)2} n (6), {[Ni(HDPA)2(H2MDP)2]} n (7), and [Ni(SBA)(H2MDP)] n (8) {where H2OBA = 4,4′-oxybis(benzoic acid), H2FBA = 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid), H2IPA = isophthalic acid, H2ADA =1,3-adamantanediacetic acid, H2TNBA = 5,5′-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzoic acid), H2PPA 1,4-phenylenedipropionic acid, H2DPA = diphenic acid H2SBA= 4,4′-sulfonyldibenzoic acid}. The majority of these MOFs exhibit a reasonably high amount of porosity, which is subsequently confirmed by N2, H2, and CO2 gas adsorption isotherms. Furthermore, results obtained from solid state CD spectra showing helicity-induced chirality for compounds 4 and 5 have also been described.

Although V-shaped ligands have a natural tendency to form helical topology, the mere presence of a ligand with bent conformation is certainly not the sole prerequisite for helical MOF construction. Particularly, in the presence of an auxiliary ligand the resultant topology becomes even more unpredictable and can mar a well-defined strategy of helical network construction. Notwithstanding, use of a V-shaped auxiliary ligand can be considered an attractive design strategy because of the possibility of unanticipated but remarkable structural variation, resulting from the mutual impact of two such ligands on the self-assembly process. In principle, by employing a combination of two bent ligands, one can have four distinctly different structural features in the resultant network: (i) a single composite helical architecture with equal participation of both the ligands; (ii) a MOF containing two different helical motifs each comprised of only one type of ligand; (iii) one of the ligands taking part in helical network formation and the other remaining inactive; (iv) none of the ligand molecule forming any helical network. Coincidentally, the crystal structures reported in this paper can also be categorized under any one of the above-mentioned sections.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Although V-shaped ligands have a natural tendency to form helical topology, the mere presence of a ligand with bent conformation is certainly not the sole prerequisite for helical MOF construction. Particularly, in the presence of an auxiliary ligand the resultant topology becomes even more unpredictable and can mar a well-defined strategy of helical network construction. Notwithstanding, use of a V-shaped auxiliary ligand can be considered an attractive design strategy because of the possibility of unanticipated but remarkable structural variation, resulting from the mutual impact of two such ligands on the self-assembly process. In principle, by employing a combination of two bent ligands, one can have four distinctly different structural features in the resultant network: (i) a single composite helical architecture with equal participation of both the ligands; (ii) a MOF containing two different helical motifs each comprised of only one type of ligand; (iii) one of the ligands taking part in helical network formation and the other remaining inactive; (iv) none of the ligand molecule forming any helical network. Coincidentally, the crystal structures reported in this paper can also be categorized under any one of the above-mentioned sections.

elements.content: A single composite helical architecture wherein both the ligands show self-assembly patterns that are typically observed in their respective helical structures would be the most interesting target network but, at the same time, a difficult task to achieve. Such composite packing also highlights the importance of both the ligands in directing the helical self-assembly process, as evident from the crystal structures of three such compounds, 1, 2, and 3. The inspiration for composite helical networks comes from the crystal structure of 1. Compound 1 crystallizes in monoclinic C2/c space group, and the asymmetric unit contains one Ni atom, one H2MDP molecule, one OBA2– molecule, and one coordinated water molecule along with one disordered lattice DMF molecule. The crystal structure can be better described using the secondary building unit (SBU) concept. The H2MDP molecule has a tendency to form a M2L2 (M = metal, L = H2MDP) type metallocyclic motif, which can be utilized as a vertex (SBU) for MOF generation. Furthermore, our recent results show that such SBUs can be used for generation of a SBU-based helical network by connecting them with a V-shaped auxiliary ligand. In the present context, the OBA2– molecule plays the role of bent exobidentate bridging ligand to connect the SBUs along the b axis to form an infinite spring like helical chain. The SBUs of two juxtaposed helical chains were further interconnected by OBA2– molecules to generate a 2D layer pattern (Figure ). Interestingly, these stacked layers, which are almost identical in nature, have a striking difference in terms of their handedness of the helical components. A careful investigation would reveal that the helical chain of the alternate layer exhibits one particular handedness, either left-handed or right-handed. Subsequently, these layers self-assemble in pairs which lead to a racemic compound with the centrosymmetric space group C2/c. Such self-assembly of the layers lead to the formation of interesting one-dimensional nanosized tubular channels running along the c axis, filled with noncoordinating solvent molecules. The presence of such distinct lattice solvent-filled channels inside the network enhances the potential of compound 1 as absorbent molecule. Indeed, as described in a later section, compound 1 shows reasonably high surface area with moderately high N2 gas uptake.
elements.clean_text:
Elucidation of Crystal Structures 1-8 

Both ligands playing an equal role in forming a single composite helical architecture

A single composite helical architecture wherein both the ligands show self-assembly patterns that are typically observed in their respective helical structures would be the most interesting target network but, at the same time, a difficult task to achieve. Such composite packing also highlights the importance of both the ligands in directing the helical self-assembly process, as evident from the crystal structures of three such compounds, 1, 2, and 3. The inspiration for composite helical networks comes from the crystal structure of 1. Compound 1 crystallizes in monoclinic C2/c space group, and the asymmetric unit contains one Ni atom, one H2MDP molecule, one OBA2- molecule, and one coordinated water molecule along with one disordered lattice DMF molecule. The crystal structure can be better described using the secondary building unit (SBU) concept. The H2MDP molecule has a tendency to form a M2L2 (M = metal, L = H2MDP) type metallocyclic motif, which can be utilized as a vertex (SBU) for MOF generation. Furthermore, our recent results show that such SBUs can be used for generation of a SBU-based helical network by connecting them with a V-shaped auxiliary ligand. In the present context, the OBA2- molecule plays the role of bent exobidentate bridging ligand to connect the SBUs along the b axis to form an infinite spring like helical chain. The SBUs of two juxtaposed helical chains were further interconnected by OBA2- molecules to generate a 2D layer pattern (Figure ). Interestingly, these stacked layers, which are almost identical in nature, have a striking difference in terms of their handedness of the helical components. A careful investigation would reveal that the helical chain of the alternate layer exhibits one particular handedness, either left-handed or right-handed. Subsequently, these layers self-assemble in pairs which lead to a racemic compound with the centrosymmetric space group C2/c. Such self-assembly of the layers lead to the formation of interesting one-dimensional nanosized tubular channels running along the c axis, filled with noncoordinating solvent molecules. The presence of such distinct lattice solvent-filled channels inside the network enhances the potential of compound 1 as absorbent molecule. Indeed, as described in a later section, compound 1 shows reasonably high surface area with moderately high N2 gas uptake.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 1 prompts us to explore the generality of forming such helical networks using similar bent auxiliary ligands. Close resemblance among H2OBA, H2FBA, and H2SBA with respect to their size, shape, and angular disposition of coordinating carboxylate groups make the latter two acids a natural choice for further study. Compound 8 with H2SBA as auxiliary ligand does not form a helical network and will be discussed in a later . Compound 2 with H2FBA as auxiliary ligand, on the other hand, also forms a single composite helical architecture comprising both the ligands. However, there are some subtle differences. Unlike compound 1, the H2MDP molecules do not form any M2L2 type SBU for compound 2. Instead, the metal centers are alternatively bridged by both the ligands to form a 1D helical nanochannel running along the crystallographic a axis. It is imperative to note here that the formation of a single-stranded helix with the participation of two V-shaped ligands is not common. Interestingly, compound 2 shows a remarkable similarity with compound 1, with alternative arrangement of opposite-handed helical chains as illustrated in Figure a.

elements.content: From a topological point of view, the 1D channels are further interconnected by H2MDP molecule to generate the final 2D frameworks, which subsequently undergo interdigitation, supported by several hydrogen bonds and extensive π–π stacking. Interestingly, the CF3 groups adopt an exo orientation and are situated at the outer wall of the helical channels, which results in a sufficient large void space inside the network, filled with solvent molecules.

elements.content: Successful construction of helical networks of 1 and 2 do speak for the usefulness of V-shaped ligands. Naturally, we were interested in exploring other bent ligands such as isophthalic acid, a well-known linker for generating helical networks with an angular orientation of ca. 120° between the coordinating sites. As expected, compound 3 also follows the trend of composite helix formation with active participation of both IPA and H2MDP molecules. The crystal structure analysis reveals a familiar SBU-based helical network formation wherein the H2MDP molecules again take part in the characteristic M2L2 type SBU formation. However, compared with the alternative arrangement of SBU and OBA in 1, two adjacent SBUs in 3 are now separated by three metal-coordinated IPA molecules. Occurrence of an alternative arrangement of left-handed and right-handed helical motifs is a recurrent theme (Figure ). Furthermore, the adjacent opposite-handed helical chains are joined together by the IPA molecules and lead to the formation of substantially large 1D columnar channel along the crystallographic a axis. The dimension of the channel can be assigned as 15.00 Å × 13.03 Å (based on Ni···Ni distance). This results in a considerable amount of cavity inside the network, which is occupied by the solvent molecules. On the basis of PLATON calculations, the potential void space in the open channels constitutes an impressive 22.1% (2333.4 Å3 of 10558.1 Å3) of the crystal volume. Such porous networks are immensely important from a gas sorption and storage point of view, and as discussed in the later , compound 3 indeed shows some interesting gas sorption behavior.

elements.content: Introduction of H2ADA and H2TNBA as the auxiliary ligand results in another variety of MOF (4 and 5), which is made of two different of helical motifs, each comprising only one type of ligand. This is in stark contrast to the helical motifs of 1–3 wherein only one helical chain was formed involving both the ligands. Nonetheless, side-by-side coexistence of two distinctive helical motifs further pinpoints the inherent tendency of both ligands to form helical MOFs, as well as the equal importance of two competing functional groups, namely, pyrazole and carboxylate.
elements.clean_text:
Formation of Two Different Helical Motifs, Each Comprised of Only One Type of Ligand

Introduction of H2ADA and H2TNBA as the auxiliary ligand results in another variety of MOF (4 and 5), which is made of two different of helical motifs, each comprising only one type of ligand. This is in stark contrast to the helical motifs of 1-3 wherein only one helical chain was formed involving both the ligands. Nonetheless, side-by-side coexistence of two distinctive helical motifs further pinpoints the inherent tendency of both ligands to form helical MOFs, as well as the equal importance of two competing functional groups, namely, pyrazole and carboxylate.

elements.content: Compound 4 crystallizes in an orthorhombic C2221 space group with one-half of an octahedral Ni(II) atom, half of a H2MDP molecule, half of an ADA molecule, and a noncoordinating half a molecule of methanol in the asymmetric unit. Topologically, the crystal structure of 4 has an interesting two-dimensional noninterpenetrating (4,4) type grid network, considering the metal center as a vertex. However, unlike most of the 2D (4,4) grid networks, it is neither planar nor rectangular in shape but adopts a highly distorted triangular geometry, resulting from the inherent bent conformations of H2MDP and ADA molecules. However, this unusual undulation of the network is consistent with an alternative array of helical strands of H2MDP and ADA molecules. As illustrated in Figure , the grid network was formed when both the helices joined together at alternate metal centers; that is each side of the grid is basically half of the pitch of the individual helix. It is worth mentioning here that (4,4) grid frameworks with helical units constructed from mixed ligands are rare.

elements.content: Compound 5, on the other hand, exhibits another unusual one-dimensional triple helical network, comprising helical units made of individual ligands. Compound 5 crystallizes in an orthorhombic P2 12121 space group with a Ni(II) atom, two symmetry independent H2MDP molecules, and a doubly deprotonated TNBA2– molecule in the asymmetric unit. The metal center adopts a distorted octahedral geometry where four nitrogen atoms from four different H2MDP molecules coordinate from the basal position and two carboxylate oxygen atoms of the TNBA take the apical position. Such a coordination environment around the metal center leads to formation of an interesting loop where two symmetry independent H2MDP and the TNBA molecules coordinate to two adjacent metal centers in a M2L3 fashion. Subsequently, these M2L3 loops conjoin in one particular direction (along the c axis), and this results in a 1D triple helical network. The most notable and unique feature of this helical network is the absence of interweaving nature. The resultant triple helical network of 5 can be subdivided into two parts: a characteristic double helical network formation by H2MDP molecules, intersecting each other at the metal center; subsequently this double helical network is wrapped up by the metal-coordinated TNBA helical chains (Figure ).

elements.content: The above-mentioned helical networks can be envisaged as the manifestation of a fine-balance between two intrinsically similar yet competing ligands and their functional groups, pyrazole and carboxylate. However, the competing ligands can have unequal influences on the resultant structure, particularly on the helical constituent; the one that has greater influence over the other would be the determinant. This is exactly what happened for crystal structures of compounds 6 and 7, where the acid molecules turn out to have much less dominance over the conformational preference of the H2MDP molecules and behave like mere linkers.
elements.clean_text:
One of the Ligands Takes Part in Helical Network Formation While the Other Remains Inactive

The above-mentioned helical networks can be envisaged as the manifestation of a fine-balance between two intrinsically similar yet competing ligands and their functional groups, pyrazole and carboxylate. However, the competing ligands can have unequal influences on the resultant structure, particularly on the helical constituent; the one that has greater influence over the other would be the determinant. This is exactly what happened for crystal structures of compounds 6 and 7, where the acid molecules turn out to have much less dominance over the conformational preference of the H2MDP molecules and behave like mere linkers.

elements.content: Compound 6 crystallized in a P2/n space group with one-half of an octahedral Ni(II) atom, one-half of a deprotonated PPA molecule, one H2MDP molecule, and two noncoordinating symmetry independent half water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The structural analysis shows that the conformational preference of H2MDP molecules to form a helical motif prevails over the acid molecule. The H2MDP molecules form a characteristic metal coordinated infinite double helical motif. On the other hand, the acid molecules, with almost parallel orientation of the carboxylate groups, act as linker between these helical motifs. Topologically, the compound exhibits a pillared-layer network wherein the 1,4-PPA molecules act as pillars and the double helical network of H2MDP molecules constitute the layer part (Figure ). Furthermore, these pillared-layer networks undergo offset stacking with the help of N–H···O and O–H···N bonds between pyrazolyl moiety and free water molecules. The interlayer connectivity is further assisted by several π–π interactions between the pyrazole rings.

The structural analysis shows that the conformational preference of H2MDP molecules to form a helical motif prevails over the acid molecule. The H2MDP molecules form a characteristic metal coordinated infinite double helical motif. On the other hand, the acid molecules, with almost parallel orientation of the carboxylate groups, act as linker between these helical motifs. Furthermore, these pillared-layer networks undergo offset stacking with the help of N-H⋅⋅⋅O and O-H⋅⋅⋅N bonds between pyrazolyl moiety and free water molecules. The interlayer connectivity is further assisted by several π-π interactions between the pyrazole rings.

elements.content: Compound 7, on the other hand, can be envisaged as a hydrogen bonded pillared-layer network, wherein only one ligand molecule (H2MDP) takes part in helical chain formation while the other one (HDPA) remains inactive. Interestingly, unlike other structures of this report, only one carboxylate group of H2DPA is coordinated to the metal center, while the nonligating second one takes part in hydrogen bonding.

Interestingly, unlike other structures of this report, only one carboxylate group of H2DPA is coordinated to the metal center, while the nonligating second one takes part in hydrogen bonding.

elements.content: From a topological point of view, the H2MDP molecules form an interesting 2D noninterpenetrating (4,4) grid network (Figure ), considering the metal center as node. The dimension of the grid can be assigned as 15.86 Å × 15.35 Å (based on Ni/Ni distance). One of the most novel aspects of the structure is the undulated nature of the grid network, which resulted from the parallel arrangement of helical strands of H2MDP molecules, joined together at alternative metal centers. Furthermore, the monocoordinated HDPA molecules join the adjacent 2D layers with N–H···O hydrogen bond formation between carboxylic group and pyrazole moiety and results in a supramolecular pillared-layer structure.

elements.content: For the sake of completeness of this study, we also report a highly porous network of compound 8 where no helical motif was formed despite the presence of a pair of V-shaped flexible ligands. Compound 8 crystallized in a P1̅ space group with an asymmetric unit consisting of an octahedral Ni(II) atom, one doubly deprotonated SBA, and one H2MDP molecule. The H2MDP molecules once again adopt a favorable M2L2 type nonhelical self-aggregation. The SBA molecules, on the other hand, act as linkers and clamp the M2L2 motifs from both ends, which results in a ladder-like 1D polymeric network (Figure ). One of the fascinating features of compound 8 is the porosity present inside the network. When viewed along the crystallographic a axis, the resultant structures resemble an infinite 1D array of relatively large conjoined nanochannels. The dimensions of the nanochannels can be described by the through-space Ni···Ni distance of ca. 13.39 Å and S···S distance between two sulfonyl groups of SBA of ca. 19.07 Å. Moreover, what makes the structure even more interesting is that it has an open network with no guest molecules inside the cavity. However, the effective pores in the actual structure are reduced considerably due to offset stacking of adjacent 1D networks, sustained by several π–π interactions and N–H···O bonds between pyrazole and phenyl rings of the acid molecules. Nonetheless, a space-filling model of the crystal packing clearly indicates the presence of nanoporous channels in the structure, which is further supported by PLATON calculation showing a void volume of 30.7% (492.8 of 1603.9) and a considerable amount of N2 uptake. From the viewpoint of porous MOFs and gas sorption, the gas sorption results are of great significance, considering that 1D coordination polymers are rarely considered as porous absorbent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
None of the Ligands Form Any Helical Network

For the sake of completeness of this study, we also report a highly porous network of compound 8 where no helical motif was formed despite the presence of a pair of V-shaped flexible ligands. Compound 8 crystallized in a P1̅ space group with an asymmetric unit consisting of an octahedral Ni(II) atom, one doubly deprotonated SBA, and one H2MDP molecule. The H2MDP molecules once again adopt a favorable M2L2 type nonhelical self-aggregation. The SBA molecules, on the other hand, act as linkers and clamp the M2L2 motifs from both ends, which results in a ladder-like 1D polymeric network (Figure ). One of the fascinating features of compound 8 is the porosity present inside the network. When viewed along the crystallographic a axis, the resultant structures resemble an infinite 1D array of relatively large conjoined nanochannels. The dimensions of the nanochannels can be described by the through-space Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distance of ca. 13.39 Å and S⋅⋅⋅S distance between two sulfonyl groups of SBA of ca. 19.07 Å. Moreover, what makes the structure even more interesting is that it has an open network with no guest molecules inside the cavity. However, the effective pores in the actual structure are reduced considerably due to offset stacking of adjacent 1D networks, sustained by several π-π interactions and N-H⋅⋅⋅O bonds between pyrazole and phenyl rings of the acid molecules. Nonetheless, a space-filling model of the crystal packing clearly indicates the presence of nanoporous channels in the structure, which is further supported by PLATON calculation showing a void volume of 30.7% (492.8 of 1603.9) and a considerable amount of N2 uptake. From the viewpoint of porous MOFs and gas sorption, the gas sorption results are of great significance, considering that 1D coordination polymers are rarely considered as porous absorbent molecules.

elements.content: Helicity and chirality often go hand-in-hand, and their mutual interplay in chiral synthesis has become the subject of elevated interests. Chirality can be induced, via helical self-assembly, in a system through the use of a chiral substance. On the other hand, helicity, as a chiral packing motif of molecular components through spontaneous resolution, can induce chirality in a system, which may be synthesized using achiral components. In the present context, compounds 4 and 5, which are made of achiral components yet crystallize in chiral space groups (C2221 and P212121 respectively), therefore can be considered as interesting systems for the study of spontaneous resolution.
elements.clean_text:
Chirality and CD Spectra

Helicity and chirality often go hand-in-hand, and their mutual interplay in chiral synthesis has become the subject of elevated interests. Chirality can be induced, via helical self-assembly, in a system through the use of a chiral substance. On the other hand, helicity, as a chiral packing motif of molecular components through spontaneous resolution, can induce chirality in a system, which may be synthesized using achiral components. In the present context, compounds 4 and 5, which are made of achiral components yet crystallize in chiral space groups (C2221 and P212121 respectively), therefore can be considered as interesting systems for the study of spontaneous resolution.

elements.content: The solid state circular dichroism (CD) spectra recorded using diffuse reluctance technique over KBr matrix for both compounds shows a negative and positive Cotton effect at 233 and 365 nm, respectively (Figure ). Interestingly, even after repeating CD measurements with several crystals from different batches for both compounds only one type of Cotton effect was observed, establishing the case of formation of enantiomerically pure samples owing to spontaneous resolution. The origin of chirality, in the absence of any other factors such as deformity in the local environment of the metal center or asymmetric cluster formation, can be linked to the self-assembly of the helical motifs in their respective structures.

elements.content: The presence of distinct solvent filled channels and pores inside the above-mentioned frameworks prompted us to evaluate their absorbent potentials. We report herein N2 gas sorption of compounds 1, 6, and 8 along with N2, H2, and CO2 gas uptake values of compound 3. Gas adsorption measurements for compounds 1, 6, and 8 were performed at 77 K for N2 in a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 instrument at lower pressures ranging from 0 to 1 atm. For compound 3, N2 and H2 uptake measurements were performed at 77 K within the same pressure range in a Quantachrome Quadrasorb automatic volumetric instrument. However, CO2 adsorption measurements for the same were performed at 273 K temperature. In all measurements, ultrahigh-purity adsorbents (N2, H2, and CO2) were obtained by using calcium aluminosilicate adsorbents to remove trace amounts of moisture and other impurities present in these gases prior to introducing them into sample. In order to achieve partial or complete removal of solvent molecules (as observed from single crystal structures), the crystals were soaked in a 1:1 mixture of methanol and dichloromethane for 48 h. The resultant solvent-exchanged crystals were then heated at 60 °C under high vacuum for 12 h and at 150 °C for 24 h in order to remove the solvent molecules from the frameworks. Compound 8 was also treated similarly except acetonitrile is used for soaking the compound in place of methanol/dichloromethane mixture. After thermal activation of samples, retention of the framework integrity, an essential prerequisite for gas sorption experiments, was confirmed by PXRD patterns (Figure S2, ). After this treatment, a 100 mg sample of each of the compounds was loaded for gas adsorption studies, and validity of the N2, H2, and CO2 adsorption isotherms obtained was confirmed by repeating the data collection at least three times.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Studies

The presence of distinct solvent filled channels and pores inside the above-mentioned frameworks prompted us to evaluate their absorbent potentials. We report herein N2 gas sorption of compounds 1, 6, and 8 along with N2, H2, and CO2 gas uptake values of compound 3. Gas adsorption measurements for compounds 1, 6, and 8 were performed at 77 K for N2 in a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 instrument at lower pressures ranging from 0 to 1 atm. For compound 3, N2 and H2 uptake measurements were performed at 77 K within the same pressure range in a Quantachrome Quadrasorb automatic volumetric instrument. However, CO2 adsorption measurements for the same were performed at 273 K temperature. In all measurements, ultrahigh-purity adsorbents (N2, H2, and CO2) were obtained by using calcium aluminosilicate adsorbents to remove trace amounts of moisture and other impurities present in these gases prior to introducing them into sample. In order to achieve partial or complete removal of solvent molecules (as observed from single crystal structures), the crystals were soaked in a 1:1 mixture of methanol and dichloromethane for 48 h. The resultant solvent-exchanged crystals were then heated at 60 °C under high vacuum for 12 h and at 150 °C for 24 h in order to remove the solvent molecules from the frameworks. Compound 8 was also treated similarly except acetonitrile is used for soaking the compound in place of methanol/dichloromethane mixture. After thermal activation of samples, retention of the framework integrity, an essential prerequisite for gas sorption experiments, was confirmed by PXRD patterns (Figure S2, ). After this treatment, a 100 mg sample of each of the compounds was loaded for gas adsorption studies, and validity of the N2, H2, and CO2 adsorption isotherms obtained was confirmed by repeating the data collection at least three times.

elements.content: The porous nature of 1, 6, and 8 was confirmed by the N2 uptake measurements with typical type-I isotherms. Compound 1 adsorbs 145 cm3/g of N2 with a considerably high BET surface area of 392 m2/g. On the other hand, compound 8 shows a relatively high surface area of 426 m2/g with a N2 gas uptake value of 171 cm3/g (Figure ). The Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution (Figure S3, ) was calculated for compounds 1 and 8 and confirms the average pore size for compound 1 between 1.5 to 3.0 nm and that for compound 8 increased slightly to the range of 1.6–4.0 nm. The N2 uptake values are reasonably high at lower pressure ranges and highlight the usefulness as adsorbent materials. This is particularly significant for compound 8, considering its one-dimensional topology. It is imperative to note here, even after tremendous advancement in the field of porous MOFs, researchers are still skeptical about the adsorbent capabilities of one-dimensional polymeric networks, and they have hardly been used for gas sorption studies.

elements.content: Interestingly, compound 3 shows reasonably high uptake of N2, H2, and CO2. Gas adsorption measurements were performed at 77 K for N2 and H2 and at 273 K for CO2 using a pressure range of 0 to 1 atm. The N2 adsorption experiments show a typical type-I isotherm (Figure a) with BET and Langmuir surface area of 305 and 493 m2/g, respectively. The BJH pore size distribution calculated from the same isotherm adsorption branch shows most of the pores in the region of 1.5 to 2.0 nm as shown in Figure d. As illustrated in Figure b, the H2 gas sorption results show a typical type-I isotherm with a steep rise in very low pressure region (less than 0.2 atm), which subsequently reached a maximum as pressure approached 1 atm with an overall 0.9 wt % gas uptake (Figure b).

As illustrated in Figure b, the H2 gas sorption results show a typical type-I isotherm with a steep rise in very low pressure region (less than 0.2 atm), which subsequently reached a maximum as pressure approached 1 atm with an overall 0.9 wt % gas uptake (Figure b).

elements.content: Similar adsorption features are observed with CO2 gas uptake, which reaches its maximum as pressure reaches 1 atm with a typical type-I isotherm and an adsorption value of 2.1 mmol/g. The perfectly reversible behavior of these isotherms shows the physisorptive adsorption of these gases similar to other relevant porous materials like activated carbons, zeolites, and molecular sieves. Table summarizes all of the motifs and their properties.

Methylenebis(3, 5-dimethylpyrazole) (H2MDP) was synthesized by a published procedure. All reagents and chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet MAGNA-IR 750 spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. Thermal analyses were carried out with a TA Instruments SDT Q600. Powder patterns of the samples were recorded in a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer; gas adsorption analysis and pore size distribution calculation were performed in a Quantachrome Quadrasorb automatic volumetric instrument and Quantachrome Autosorb 1 instrument. CD measurements were carried out in a JASCO J-815 spectrometer in KBr matrix.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

Methylenebis(3, 5-dimethylpyrazole) (H2MDP) was synthesized by a published procedure. All reagents and chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet MAGNA-IR 750 spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. Thermal analyses were carried out with a TA Instruments SDT Q600. Powder patterns of the samples were recorded in a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer; gas adsorption analysis and pore size distribution calculation were performed in a Quantachrome Quadrasorb automatic volumetric instrument and Quantachrome Autosorb 1 instrument. CD measurements were carried out in a JASCO J-815 spectrometer in KBr matrix.

The mixture was heated at 120 °C for 72 h in a Teflon lined autoclave under autogenous pressure. On slow cooling of the autoclave to room temperature, block shaped green crystals of compound 1 were obtained in 50% yield. elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of 1-8 

Synthesis of {[Ni(OBA)(H2MDP)(H2O)]⋅(DMF)3} n  (1)

To a mixture of Ni(NO3)2, H2MDP, and H2OBA, 2 mL of methanol, 1 mL of DMF, and 1 mL of water were added. The mixture was heated at 120 °C for 72 h in a Teflon lined autoclave under autogenous pressure. On slow cooling of the autoclave to room temperature, block shaped green crystals of compound 1 were obtained in 50% yield. elements.content: X-ray diffraction intensities for compounds 1–8 were collected at 120 K on Bruker APEX-2 CCD and diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation and processed using SAINT. The structures were solved by direct methods in SHELXS and refined by full matrix least-squares on F 2 in SHELXL. Crystallographic data are summarized in Table , and CIF files for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC). Deposition numbers are given in Table . Copies of the data can be obtained, free of charge, on application to the CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, U.K. (fax 44 (1223) 336 033; e-mail deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

X-ray diffraction intensities for compounds 1-8 were collected at 120 K on Bruker APEX-2 CCD and diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation and processed using SAINT. The structures were solved by direct methods in SHELXS and refined by full matrix least-squares on F 2 in SHELXL. Crystallographic data are summarized in Table , and CIF files for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC). Deposition numbers are given in Table . Copies of the data can be obtained, free of charge, on application to the CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, U.K. (fax 44 (1223) 336 033; e-mail deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

The impetus of the work presented herein is to rationalize the behavior of V-shaped ligands toward helix formation in metal–organic frameworks. Mutual interplay of such ligands has generated several interesting architectures containing both helical and nonhelical motifs. The strategy of using a combination of ligand molecules, each capable of forming helical networks, is novel and should enable us to design helical MOFs of interesting topology. Furthermore, solid state CD spectra and gas sorption data highlight the potential of these molecules as chiral zeolite analogues.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The impetus of the work presented herein is to rationalize the behavior of V-shaped ligands toward helix formation in metal-organic frameworks. Mutual interplay of such ligands has generated several interesting architectures containing both helical and nonhelical motifs. The strategy of using a combination of ligand molecules, each capable of forming helical networks, is novel and should enable us to design helical MOFs of interesting topology. Furthermore, solid state CD spectra and gas sorption data highlight the potential of these molecules as chiral zeolite analogues.

cln_elements.content:
Successful construction of helical networks of 1 and 2 do speak for the usefulness of V-shaped ligands. Naturally, we were interested in exploring other bent ligands such as isophthalic acid, a well-known linker for generating helical networks with an angular orientation of ca. 120° between the coordinating sites. As expected, compound 3 also follows the trend of composite helix formation with active participation of both IPA and H2MDP molecules. The crystal structure analysis reveals a familiar SBU-based helical network formation wherein the H2MDP molecules again take part in the characteristic M2L2 type SBU formation. However, compared with the alternative arrangement of SBU and OBA in 1, two adjacent SBUs in 3 are now separated by three metal-coordinated IPA molecules. Occurrence of an alternative arrangement of left-handed and right-handed helical motifs is a recurrent theme (Figure ). Furthermore, the adjacent opposite-handed helical chains are joined together by the IPA molecules and lead to the formation of substantially large 1D columnar channel along the crystallographic a axis. The dimension of the channel can be assigned as 15.00 Å × 13.03 Å (based on Ni···Ni distance). This results in a considerable amount of cavity inside the network, which is occupied by the solvent molecules. On the basis of PLATON calculations, the potential void space in the open channels constitutes an impressive 22.1% (2333.4 Å3 of 10558.1 Å3) of the crystal volume. Such porous networks are immensely important from a gas sorption and storage point of view, and as discussed in the later , compound 3 indeed shows some interesting gas sorption behavior.

From a topological point of view, the H2MDP molecules form an interesting 2D noninterpenetrating (4,4) grid network (Figure ), considering the metal center as node. The dimension of the grid can be assigned as 15.86 Å × 15.35 Å (based on Ni/Ni distance). One of the most novel aspects of the structure is the undulated nature of the grid network, which resulted from the parallel arrangement of helical strands of H2MDP molecules, joined together at alternative metal centers. Furthermore, the monocoordinated HDPA molecules join the adjacent 2D layers with N–H···O hydrogen bond formation between carboxylic group and pyrazole moiety and results in a supramolecular pillared-layer structure.

The porous nature of 1, 6, and 8 was confirmed by the N2 uptake measurements with typical type-I isotherms. Compound 1 adsorbs 145 cm3/g of N2 with a considerably high BET surface area of 392 m2/g. On the other hand, compound 8 shows a relatively high surface area of 426 m2/g with a N2 gas uptake value of 171 cm3/g (Figure ). The Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution (Figure S3, ) was calculated for compounds 1 and 8 and confirms the average pore size for compound 1 between 1.5 to 3.0 nm and that for compound 8 increased slightly to the range of 1.6–4.0 nm. The N2 uptake values are reasonably high at lower pressure ranges and highlight the usefulness as adsorbent materials. This is particularly significant for compound 8, considering its one-dimensional topology. It is imperative to note here, even after tremendous advancement in the field of porous MOFs, researchers are still skeptical about the adsorbent capabilities of one-dimensional polymeric networks, and they have hardly been used for gas sorption studies.

For compound 6, the amount of N2 adsorbed decreases significantly to a value of 24 cm3/g with a reasonably smaller BET surface area of 39 m2/g. Compounds 1, 6, and 8 were also tested for CO2 uptake, but unfortunately no significant CO2 uptake was observed.

Interestingly, compound 3 shows reasonably high uptake of N2, H2, and CO2. Gas adsorption measurements were performed at 77 K for N2 and H2 and at 273 K for CO2 using a pressure range of 0 to 1 atm. The N2 adsorption experiments show a typical type-I isotherm (Figure a) with BET and Langmuir surface area of 305 and 493 m2/g, respectively. The BJH pore size distribution calculated from the same isotherm adsorption branch shows most of the pores in the region of 1.5 to 2.0 nm as shown in Figure d. As illustrated in Figure b, the H2 gas sorption results show a typical type-I isotherm with a steep rise in very low pressure region (less than 0.2 atm), which subsequently reached a maximum as pressure approached 1 atm with an overall 0.9 wt % gas uptake (Figure b).

Similar adsorption features are observed with CO2 gas uptake, which reaches its maximum as pressure reaches 1 atm with a typical type-I isotherm and an adsorption value of 2.1 mmol/g. The perfectly reversible behavior of these isotherms shows the physisorptive adsorption of these gases similar to other relevant porous materials like activated carbons, zeolites, and molecular sieves. Table summarizes all of the motifs and their properties.

(b) The H2 adsorption isotherms collected at 77 K for compound 3 showing physisorptive adsorption behavior with steep rise in the very low pressure range. (d) BJH pore size distribution for compound 3 showing narrow distribution of pores. Filled and open circles represent adsorption and desorption branches, respectively.
